title: England 40-16 Australia: Kyle Sinckler keeps head to win England semi-final spot
text:
Get the biggest daily news stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

History repeated itself as ruthless England stormed into the semi-finals of the Rugby World Cup - with a helping hand from Australia, writes Alex Spink in Oita.

Twelve years after beating the Wallabies to reach the last four in France, England did so again to set up a semi-final with New Zealand.

Remarkably, just as on that day in Marseille, the catalyst for victory was an act of Aussie sledging that backfired.

In 2007 two Wallaby forwards patted hooker Mark Regan on the head after an England scrum was penalised - prompting the immortal riposte: “Hang on babs. You've got another 75 minutes to go yet."

Yesterday it was Kyle Sinckler getting the head-pat treatment, this time from Aussie hooker Tolu Latu, after conceding a free kick with an early scrum shove.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

A dozen years on and the outcome was just the same. England got mad, then they got even.

There was a time not so long ago when Sinckler would have got riled, certainly had something to say to Latu.

Instead, like Regan before him, he let his rugby do his talking - first with England’s crucial third try, then by winning a turnover on his own line to protect the victory.

(Image: MARK R CRISTINO/EPA-EFE/REX)

“That's something I've really tried to own….my discipline and just being cool in the moment,” said the Harlequins prop. “That comes with experience.”

Later Eddie Jones would dub Sinckler a “runaway rhino”. Team mate Joe Marler preferred a “young runaway bull”. Either way Australia got the gist.

They had been swept away after their strong start, dominated by Sinckler and ‘Kamikaze Kids’ Tom Curry and Sam Underhill in the most emphatic fashion.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Jonny May marked his 50th cap with two tries in two minutes at the end of the first quarter, Anthony Watson bagged an interception score and captain Owen Farrell silenced his critics by slotting all eight of his shots at goal.

But nobody contributed more than Sinckler, 26, erasing the memory of losing his rag in Cardiff in the Six Nations after being wound up by Wales boss Warren Gatland.

“There have been in the past questions about Kyle’s emotional energy, which is what he thrives off,” said Marler. “In the Six Nations he wasn’t able to control that.

(Image: AFLO/Press Association Images)

(Image: PA)

“But here he showed he’s now fully able to do so and play on that edge, which was great to see.”

Of all the images to be recalled from this day on the island of Kyushu, none was more than striking than Sinckler’s smile as he ran a perfect line onto Farrell’s pass to score under the sticks.

“It was very special,” he admitted. “But I was knackered afterwards. That was a tough, tough Test match.”

(Image: Getty Images,)

It got tougher still when Australia came again, pounding at the England line with a refusal to accept their World Cup dream was over.

It seemed they would finally breach the white defence but in the nick of time the ball popped loose, forced out of Isi Naisarani’s grasp by Sinckler.

Now was the time to give Sinckler a pat. But Australia had missed their cue. And paid the ultimate price.

England - Tries: May 2, Sinckler, Watson. Cons: Farrell 4. Pens: Farrell 4.

Australia - Try: Koroibete. Con: Lealiifano. Pens: Lealiifano 3.
description: Eddie Jones' team win by four tries to one to set up last-four clash against New Zealand, 46-14 winners over Ireland
